prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context

para.paratext: Trade secrets have been defined by A.H. Seidel and R.L. Panitch as:

… any formula, pattern, device or compilation of information which is used in one's business, and which gives him an opportunity to obtain an advantage over competitors who do not know how to use it. It may be a formula for a chemical compound, a process of manufacturing, treating or preserving materials, a pattern for a machine or other device, or a list of customers. It differs from other secret information in a business in that it is not simply information as to single or ephemeral events in the conduct of the business … A trade secret is a process for continuous use in the operation of the business.[1]

Frequently such information is in the public domain, and anyone is at liberty to discover a particular trade secret by any fair means, such as experimentation and analysis of a particular product, or even by casual observation … Moreover, upon discovery, the idea may be used with impunity; and therefore a plurality of individual discoverers may have protectable, wholly separate rights in the same trade secret.[2]
In short, if an idea is of a commercial nature, provides a competitive advantage, is used in business and is kept in secrecy, it may be protected by trade secret law.

Unlike the patent and copyright laws, however, trade secret law does not purport to grant an inventor a monopoly in the trade secret. The only protection afforded a trade secret owner is against acquisition by improper means or breach of confidence. Trade secret law does not prohibit either independent development or acquisition by any proper means.[3]
A.H. Seidel and R.L. Panitch, What the General Practitioner Should Know about Trade Secrets and Employment Agreements (Philadelphia: American Law Institute, 1973), p. 173.
